Award.AwardTitle: Bayesian Network for Structural Health Monitoring and Decision

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The purpose of the project is to develop a Bayesian network-based decision making framework for effective utilization of structural health monitoring systems with inherent uncertainties. The information gained from health monitoring systems is often highly uncertain, leading to decisions about inspection schedules, maintenance, repair, retrofit, or closure/continued operation of a facility that are not completely clear. The Bayesian network, extended with utility and decision nodes, will be used to provide quantitative and graphical representation for near-real time information processing and decision making about monitored structural systems. The proposed framework will offer transparency in modeling and interaction with non-experts, modeling of complex interdependent systems, and ability to learn from data to provide near-real time decision making. The methodology will be applied to three demonstrative applications: a monitored building structure subjected to a severe earthquake for near-real time post-earthquake decision making; a continuously monitored bridge for inspection and maintenance decisions to minimize life-cycle cost; and selection of the best among a set of candidate structural health monitoring systems based on the value of information they provide.
The project is expected to facilitate effective and objective use of health monitoring systems in practice, leading to mitigate losses due to natural and man-made hazards. The methodology will improve the ability of emergency responders to make optimal decisions after a major hazard, such as a severe earthquake, or managers of constructed facilities to implement inspection and maintenance plans in order to minimize life-cycle cost, thereby benefiting society. The project will provide multidisciplinary training to a graduate student and to undergraduate summer interns, improve existing undergraduate and graduate courses, and enhance international research collaboration with a European country.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This research developed advanced tools for structural health monitoring and condition assessment of structural and infrastructure systems. Structural and infrastructure systems are increasingly monitored by use of sensors. During ambient or forced vibration of these systems, sensors provide information about the structural response. We use these sensor measurements to identify the properties of the system and assess its condition. Unavoidable uncertainties prevail this process. These include the stochastic nature of the excitations that are input into the system, the uncertainty in the system itself, and measurement noise. Therefore, to identify the system parameters or state, it is necessary to make use of probabilistic methods. In our research, we have advocated and developed Bayesian techniques. These techniques are useful because they properly account for the prevailing uncertainties and they can employ any type of information (measurement or observation), including cases where the information evolves in time. Furthermore, in light of the prevailing uncertainties, Bayesian methods provide a probabilistic assessment of the system properties (e.g., distributions on system parameters) or the system state (e.g., the probability that the system is in a particular state). This type of probabilistic assessment can be used in a decision support system to make decisions on operation or closure of facilities after a major hazardous event, such as an earthquake.

Bayesian methods can be computationally extremely demanding. In this research, we have developed new algorithms and formulations for two advanced Bayesian techniques: Bayesian network for modeling of infrastructure systems and variational Bayes method for system identification. These developments have advanced the state-of-the-art of applying Bayesian methods to structural health monitoring and condition assessment of infrastructure systems. These advances allow consideration of larger and more general infrastructure systems.
